II. 

RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

A. 

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

Solomon Islands is a large Melanesian island country, with a land area of about 28,000 
2. 
square  kilometers,  comprising  six  large  islands,  dozens  of  smaller  islands,  and  hundreds  of 
islets and atolls. More than 80% of the population of 475,000 is rural, living in widely dispersed 
villages  of  a  few  hundred  persons.  The  country,  especially  in  rural  areas,  lacks  adequate 
infrastructure  and  services.  The  Project  will  improve  the  efficiency  and  effectiveness  of  the 
national road network to increase rural accessibility and promote development. The design and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 

Solomon Islands is a weakly performing country1 emerging from several years of conflict 
3. 
(1999–2003), and is one of the least developed of the Asian Development Bank’s (ADB) Pacific 
developing  member  countries.  In  the  United  Nations’  Human  Development  Index,  Solomon 
Islands  ranks  second  lowest  among  Pacific  island  countries.  The  country  is  unlikely  to  meet 
most  of  the  Millennium  Development  Goals  by  2015.  The  socioeconomic  situation  is 
characterized  by  high  unemployment  (about  75%  of  the  population  is  not  formally  employed), 
especially among the youth, and rapid population growth. The population growth rate of 2.9% is 
among  the  highest  in  the  world.  Combined  with  slow  economic  growth,  the  socioeconomic 
situation exacerbates poverty. 

4. 
The  economy  is  based  on  primary  commodities  from  agriculture,  forestry,  and  fishing. 
Jobs  are  limited,  with  only  about  a  quarter  of  the  population  formally  employed.  Income-
generating  opportunities  are  scarce  in  rural  areas.  During  the  conflict,  real  gross  domestic 
product  (GDP)  per  capita  declined  by  35%  to  about  $500.  Since  2003,  GDP  growth  has 
averaged  4–5%  per  year.  Still,  the  International  Monetary  Fund  and  Central  Bank  of  Solomon 
Islands estimate that the economy will require another 20 years to return to the pre-conflict level 
of GDP per capita. 

5. 
The  road  network  is sparse,  reaching  only  23%  of  rural  villages  with about  20% of  the 
national  population.  About  60%  of  the  network  is  on  Guadalcanal  and  Malaita,  which  serve 
about 90% of the traffic in the country. Sealed or graveled roads are confined to Guadalcanal 
and Malaita, which also have the only significant inland roads, and a segment of secondary road 
in Western Province. Other provinces have relatively short coastal segments of gravel or earth 
roads near provincial centers. The network has about 185 watercourse crossings, mostly small 
log bridges with few steel or reinforced concrete structures. A sector analysis is in Appendix 2. 

6. 
Investment in the road network, which never has been adequate, has declined in recent 
years,  leaving  the  sector  badly  underfunded  and  deteriorating.  Development  partners  have 
funded  most  of  the  road  construction,  providing  $81  million  over  the  past  15  years.  That  is 
equivalent  to  about  18%  of  the  Government’s  development  budget  in  those  years.  Over  the 
same  period,  the  Government  invested  about  $9  million  and  committed  an  average  of  about 
$0.5 million per year in maintenance funding through the recurrent budget. External assistance 
is summarized in Appendix 3.

documents of other development partners active in the country.

The  road  network  has  been  constructed  with  poor  design  standards  and  materials. 
7. 
About  8%  of  national  roads  are  sealed,  about  61%  are  gravel  surfaced,  and  the  rest  are 
earthen. Shoulders are nonexistent, and drainage is poorly constructed and maintained. Roads 
throughout  the  country  have  deteriorated  due  to  years  of  neglect  and  deferred  maintenance. 
Only about 20% of the roads in Solomon Islands are estimated to be in good or fair condition; 
the remainder are so deteriorated that they are impassable by cars and light trucks, and need 
rehabilitation. Similarly, as bridges have exceeded their design life, only about 25% are in good 
condition,  with  30%  needing  minor  repairs,  37%  requiring  major  repairs,  and  8%  closed  to 
traffic. The condition of the network does not provide much rural accessibility or optimize road 
agency  and  road  user  costs,  thus  restricting  the  contribution  of  road  transport  to  economic 
growth, poverty reduction, and social development.  

The  poor  condition  of  many  roads  has  lowered  travel  speeds,  increased  fuel 
8. 
consumption,  and  raised  vehicle  operating  costs.  Rough  surfaces  also  have  reduced  the 
economic lives of the vehicles and suppressed road transport demand. Outside Honiara, road 
transport costs are estimated to be 25% higher, and travel speeds are approximately half what 
they  would  be  if  the  roads  were  in  good  condition.  Road  access  for  rural  areas  has  declined 
dramatically due to severe deterioration, road closures, and collapsed bridges.  

9. 
Due to the sparse road network, the main form of transport in rural areas is by small boat 
around  coastal  areas.  Road  transport  services  are  provided  by  small-scale  private  companies 
and informally by a few vehicle owner-operators using market trucks, tractors, and small vans. 
There are no publicly operated transport services, nor is there regulation of passenger or freight 
charges. Traffic volumes are very low outside of Honiara. 

The  Ministry  of  Infrastructure  and  Development  (MID)  is  responsible  for  road 
10. 
development  and  maintenance.  Maintenance  funding  has  been  inadequate,  and  works  have 
typically been carried out by MID’s own forces. Opportunities for the private sector have been 
limited  and  uneven,  constraining  its  development.  Before  the  conflict,  MID  maintained  a  large 
labor force that was not always fully utilized. Staffing levels fell greatly during the conflict, and 
have not been restored. MID has recognized the need to rebuild its skills in asset planning and 
management,  contract  administration,  and  policy  and  strategy  development.  As  a  result,  it  is 
now recruiting more professional staff and training them with ADB assistance.  

1. 

Government’s Sector Strategy 

11. 
The  Government’s  development  vision,  priorities,  and  strategies  are  articulated  in  the 
National  Economic  Recovery,  Reform,  and  Development  Plan  2003–2006  (NERRDP).2  It 
identifies key strategic areas for revitalizing the productive sector and rebuilding infrastructure, 
and  for  restoring  basic  social  services  and  fostering  social  development.  The  NERRDP 
recognizes  the  importance  of  transport  infrastructure  as  an  enabling  input  for  community 
development.  The  Government  expects  that  implementation  of  the  plan,  with  a  preferential 
focus  on  disadvantaged  and  rural  populations,  will  lead  to  more  equitable  distribution  of 
increasing  incomes,  social  services,  and  development  among  provinces,  social  groups,  and 
genders.  All  stakeholders  agree  that  the  NERRDP  is  the  appropriate  basis  for  prioritizing  and 
coordinating  sector  activities.  The  Government  has  asked  ADB  to  take  the  lead  among 
development partners in coordinating assistance to the transport sector.

13. 
The Transport Sector Strategy will be implemented according to the National Transport

works program that  will be updated annually. An official Transport Task Force (TTF) including 
representatives  of  Government,  transport  users,  and  transport  service  providers  has  been 
established to advise on key issues, development options, and prioritization. 

2. 

ADB’s Sector Strategy and Program 

14. 
Infrastructure investments are needed to support economic growth, employment, poverty 
reduction, and social development. ADB’s country strategy and program update for 2006–20075 
prioritizes  two  major  areas  for  ADB  assistance:  transportation  infrastructure  and  services,  and 
an enabling business environment. It also identifies institutional capacity development as central 
to all activities. These three themes are complementary. 

ADB  is  implementing  the  Post-Conflict  Emergency  Rehabilitation  Project6  (PCERP)  to 
15.

conflict.  A  project  management  unit  operates  under  the  direction  of  a  project  steering 
committee,  comprising  representatives  from  the  ministries  responsible  for  finance,  planning, 
national unity, and provincial government, as well as the concerned sectoral ministries. Physical 
works, which began in June 2005 and are about 30% complete, are scheduled for completion in 
February 2007. A recent change of scope, cofinanced by the Government of Australia and the 
Government of New Zealand, enabled ADB to expand this project.  

To  leverage  scarce  public  sector  resources  and  promote  opportunities  for  the  private 
16.

B. 

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities  

18. 
As  a  weakly  performing  country  emerging  from  several  years  of  conflict,  Solomon 
Islands is confronting many challenges and opportunities. The most pressing issues include (i) 
sustained economic growth, (ii) increased employment and income-generating opportunities, (iii) 
an improved institutional framework to manage and administer public sector responsibilities, and 
(iv) improved human and institutional capacity. Progress in these areas is expected to contribute 
directly to poverty reduction. A review of road sector activities, policies and institutions, capacity 
building progress, and lessons learned is in Appendix 2.

Rationale for the Project 

33. 
Pro-poor  economic  growth  and  improvement  in  social and  health  indicators  depend  on 
the  revitalization  and  decentralization  of  the  rural  economy.  The  poor  condition  of  roads  is  a 
constraint to the movement of people and goods, and a disincentive to productive rural activity. 
Improved  transportation  infrastructure  and  services,  which  would  provide  reliable  access  to 
domestic  and  international  markets  for  rural  produce  and  commodities,  are  critical  to  (i) 
restarting  and  building  rural  economies,  (ii)  reducing  migration  of  people  in  search  of 
employment,  (iii)  decreasing  conflict  between  groups  competing  for  limited  opportunities,  and 
(iv) restoring basic social services in rural areas. The focus on improving rural accessibility will 
enhance poverty reduction. 

34.  Most  previous  projects,  representing  more  than  90%  of  road  sector  investment,  have 
focused  on  Guadalcanal  and  Malaita.  The  other  seven  provinces  consistently  have  received 
less attention, and have been subject to more deferred maintenance. As a result, provincial and 
secondary roads in these other rural provinces are so badly deteriorated that they can no longer 
be maintained, and urgently need rehabilitation. The Government requested preparation of the 
Project with a preferential focus on addressing the urgent needs in the rest of the country. Final 
subproject selection will be based on the priorities established in the NTP. 

The Government has embarked on institutional reforms, with ADB assistance, to ensure

the  use  of  domestic  and  external  resources  to  reduce  constraints  caused  by  road  network 
conditions. With the comprehensive implementation assistance and capacity building under the

IV. 

PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 

64. 
The  Project  will  benefit  directly  the  rural  population,  many  of  whom  are  poor  and 
extremely poor, through better access and decreased travel time to markets and social services. 
Government agencies and private sector companies that use the roads to deliver products and 
services will benefit similarly. The estimated benefits to these groups, as well as other impacts, 
assumptions, and risks, are described in this section.   

A. 

Economic Impacts 

65. 
Rehabilitated  roads  will  improve  accessibility  for  rural  populations.  Direct  benefits  will 
include  travel  time  savings,  reduced  vehicle  operating  costs  and  fuel  use,  and  reduced 
passenger  travel  and  freight  charges  (e.g.,  shifting  from  sea  transport  to  road  transport). 
Rehabilitated  roads  are  likely  to  generate  more  traffic,  promote  more  agricultural  production, 
and  create  local  employment  during  their  construction  and  maintenance.  Rehabilitated  roads 
also will create greater access to social services, including education and health. Lower costs 
for routine maintenance will allow the Government to maintain more of the network and extend 
similar benefits to a greater proportion of the rural population. 

66. 
Economic  benefits  from  transport  cost  savings  will  flow  to  the  areas  served.  Benefits 
from lower freight transport costs will be divided between producers, consumers, and transport 
operators. Since market prices are unlikely to fall substantially, most such benefits probably will 
accrue to producers. Prices for goods imported to subproject areas might fall. 

67. 
The  NTP  (footnote  4),  which  is  based  on  a  least-cost  approach  to  achieving 
development  objectives,  identifies  the  Government’s  prioritized  list  of  potential  subprojects. 
Economic evaluations of subprojects will be carried out using the principles of the World Bank’s 
Roads  Economic  Decision  Model,  including  economic  internal  rates  of  return  and  sensitivity 
analyses.  The  evaluations  will  be  required  to  demonstrate  that  subprojects  are  economically 

 justifiable,  with  economic  internal  rates  of  return  of  at  least  12%.  They  also  will  be  used  to 
prioritize individual subprojects. Economic criteria are in Appendix 5. 

B. 

Poverty Reduction Impact  

68. 
The  Project  will  reduce  poverty  by  improving  people’s  access  to  local  and  provincial 
markets,  agricultural  fields,  water  supplies,  and  firewood,  thereby  offering  income  generation 
opportunities. The Project also will reduce poverty by offering direct employment on the project. 
During  implementation,  employment  will  be  created  in  construction  and  maintenance  for  civil 
works.  Following  completion,  employment  opportunities  will  arise  for  routine  maintenance 
conduced  through  LBES  and  traditional  methods.  By  reducing  the  cost  and  time  of  travel, 
inducing  economic  activities,  and  employing  people  directly,  the  Project  will  improve  people’s 
incomes and food security. 

69. 
During the poverty and social analysis of  the subprojects, the economic impacts of the 
Project on the poor and non-poor will be assessed using secondary and field data. Distributional 
analysis  will  not  be  needed  unless  the  initial  assessment  is  considered  insufficient,  and  if  the 
extra data collection and analysis required for distributional analysis is considered worthwhile. A 
summary  poverty  reduction  and  social  strategy  is  in  Appendix  9,  while  a  social  and  poverty 
analysis is in Supplementary Appendix A.

Other  social  benefits  include  easier  access  to  administrative  and  service  centers,  including

ROAD SECTOR ANALYSIS 

A. 

Road Network 

1. 
Solomon  Islands  has  a  road  network  of  about  1,950  kilometers  (km)  spread  over  30 
islands. The network comprises 390 km of main roads, 455 km of secondary roads, 425 km of 
provincial  roads,  120  km  of  Honiara  Town  roads,  and  about  560  km  of  private  and  plantation 
access  roads.  The country  has  an  estimated  800  km  of  logging  roads. The  road  network  also 
has about 185 bridges. Sea is the dominant mode of transport in Solomon Islands. The Ministry 
of  Infrastructure  and  Development  (MID)  manages  the  main  and  secondary  roads,  while  the 
provincial governments manage the provincial roads.   

2. 
About  60%  of  the  network  is  on  Guadalcanal  and  Malaita,  which  serves  about  90%  of 
the  traffic  in  the  country.  About  1,570  km  have  a  graveled  surface  and  about  100  km  of  main 
roads, mostly on Guadalcanal and Malaita, and 30 km of Honiara Town roads are sealed. Other 
provinces  have  relatively  short  coastal  segments  of  gravel  or  earth  roads  around  provincial 
centers. Compared to other Pacific nations, the road density is low: Solomon Islands has less 
than  0.07  km  per  square  kilometer  and  only  0.005  km  per  capita.  About  23%  of  villages  are 
accessible by road (normally by cars or trucks), 32% by sea, 40% by walking tracks, and 5% by 
river.   

The  main  roads  serve  the  densely  populated  areas  linking  the  main  centers  with 
3. 
commercial centers, markets, and main ports.  The secondary roads are extensions to the main 
road network, or serve provincial and subprovincial centers and rural communities on the main 
islands.  Provincial  roads  serve  a  similar  function  to  secondary  roads.  They  also  connect 
agricultural  areas  and  villages  to  wharves,  and  provide  access  to  social  services,  including 
schools, clinics, and markets.   

4. 
Main,  secondary,  and  provincial  roads  were  not  built  to  high  standards  and  have 
suffered  from  years  of  neglect.  As  a  result,  the  condition  of  the  network  is  poor.  It  provides 
inadequate  rural  access,  thereby  constraining  economic  growth  and  development,  poverty 
reduction, and social development. In rural areas, the potential of agriculture production of cash 
crops is underdeveloped primarily due to irregular farm-to-market access, which leaves much of 
the rural population reliant on subsistence livelihoods. Resource-based industries also rely on a 
suitable standard of roads for marketing their production for export. 

5. 
About  80%  of  roads  have  deteriorated  to  such  an  extent  that  damage  to  vehicles  is 
excessive, and the roads are impassable by cars and light trucks. Roads surfaces are deformed 
and  eroded,  drainage  is  not  working,  and  vegetation  is  overgrown.  Many  log  bridges  have 
exceeded  their  design  life,  with  only  about  25%  remaining  in  good  condition,  30%  requiring 
minor  repairs,  37%  requiring  major  repairs,  and  8%  not  open  to  traffic.  The  poor  condition  of 
many  roads  has  lowered  traveling  speeds,  while  increasing  fuel  consumption  and  vehicle 
operating costs. The rough road surfaces also have reduced the economic lives of the vehicles, 
and suppressed road transport demand. 

6. 
Development  partners  are  assisting  with  rehabilitation  road  and  bridge  works  in  areas 
worst affected by several years of conflict (1999–2003), and with the restoration of some wharf 
facilities throughout the country. However, much more needs to be done urgently.

16. 
National  Development  Plan.  The  Government’s  development  vision,  priorities,  and 
development  strategies  are  articulated  in  the  National  Economic  Recovery,  Reform  and 
Development Plan 2003–2006 (NERRDP). The overall national development goal of NERRDP 
is to enhance and improve the quality of life and living standards of all the people in Solomon 
Islands.  This  goal  is  to be  achieved  by  ensuring  peace,  harmony,  and  personal  safety  among 
the people; increasing incomes and their equitable distribution; and increasing the availability of, 
and  improving  the  access  to,  social  service  for  everyone.  This  would  lead  to  equitable 
distribution of development among all provinces and people within each province, social groups, 
and  genders.  Preferential  attention  would  be  given  to  the  disadvantaged  and  marginalized 
groups  and  communities,  including  expansion  of  development  to  rural  areas.  The  immediate 
objectives of NERRDP 2003–2006 are to (i) improve the security environment by restoring law 
and  order  and  fostering  peace,  (ii)  strengthen  and  improve  governance  institutions  and  good 
governance,  (iii)  achieve  macroeconomic  stability  and  income  growth,  (iv)  restore  basic  social 
services  in  health  and  education,  and  (v)  reestablish  the  foundations  for  sustained  economic 
growth and human development. 

17. 
The realization of these objectives hinges on increasing personal mobility and removing 
constraints to the transportation of goods between areas of production and markets. Improving 
security requires ensuring that law enforcement officers and justice administrators can respond 
quickly to emerging threats to peace and law compliance, as and where they occur. Effective, 
efficient,  and  transparent  governance  in  other  areas  of  governmental  administration  similarly 
requires improved access within outlying areas of the country. Economic growth, particularly in 
the  production  and  distribution  of  tradable  goods,  depends  on  adequate,  reliable,  affordable, 
and  secure  transportation.  Basic  health  and  education  facilities,  as  and  where  they  are  being

infrastructure in areas of most need. In the longer term, the Government’s road sector policy will 
be  to  (i)  restore  the  network  of  roads  and  bridges  to  conditions  that  promote  economic 
development and enhance social welfare and security; (ii) extend the scope of the maintainable 
road network in accordance with socioeconomic criteria; (iii) establish an effective and efficient

economically disadvantaged. 

20. 
The  Government’s  strategy  is  to  reconstruct  high-priority  roads  to  design  standards 
appropriate  to  the  traffic  and  topography.  Improvements  needed  include  repairs  and 
replacement  of  bridges,  reshaping  and  strengthening  of  pavement,  and  improvement  to 
drainage (additional culverts and cross drains). Feeder roads connecting village settlements and 
farms  with  main  roads  also  should  be  considered  for  improvement.  The  Government,  through 
development  partners,  is  (i)  rehabilitating  high-priority  roads  and  bridges  in  Guadalcanal  and 
Malaita; (ii) strengthening the capacity and capability of MID to undertake project management, 
contract management, contract supervision, and road asset management under the TA; and (iii) 
establishing a dedicated transport fund with sustainable revenues from user charges. 

21. 
The  Government’s  limited  domestic  resources  dictate  that  external  agencies  will 
continue to fund most sector development. Similarly, the low capacity and capability of the local 
construction industry requires a heavy dependence on international consultants to carry out the 
works. Asset management capability is being enhanced, enabling follow-up maintenance works 
to be carried out effectively and efficiently.

26. 
The  NTP  also  covers  organizational  reforms  and  human  resource  development 
programs  to  ensure  capacity  is  in  place  during  the  planning  period.  The  NTP  is  intended  to 
embody sufficient flexibility to meet emerging needs, constraints, and opportunities. The NTP is 
designed  to  satisfy  eligibility  criteria  associated  with  development  partner  programs.  The  NTP 
will be reviewed and updated periodically, incorporating new Government polices. 

27. 
Sector  Finance  and  the  National  Transport  Fund.  The  Government  has  invested 
about  $9.0  million  of  its  own  resources  and  $81  million  in  external  assistance  to  develop  the 
road  sector  over  the  past  15  years  (Appendix  3).  Given  the  large  investment  needs  and 
constrained public finances, the Government will continue to rely on external assistance for road 
rehabilitation and development. 

About  80%  of  the  road network  requires  reconstruction  due  to  neglected  maintenance. 
28. 
Road maintenance funding has averaged $0.5 million since 1990, with a temporary drop of 80% 
to  an  average  of  $0.1  million  during  the  conflict  (1998–2002),  resulting  in  widespread 
deterioration. Funding is significantly below the levels necessary to sustain current assets. What 
proportion  goes  toward  maintenance,  versus  public  sector  overhead  costs,  is  unclear  due  to 
limited accountability. Maintaining the 20% of roads that remain in good or fair condition would 
cost  an  estimated  $1.55  million  annually—three  times  the  current  allocation.  The  benefits  of 
road  rehabilitation  will  not  be  realized  unless  a  comprehensive  maintenance  program  is 
implemented. 

29. 
 To  address  the  shortfall  in  maintenance  funding,  the  Government  is  setting  up  a 
dedicated  National  Transport  Fund  (NTF),  supported  by  ADB  TA.  The  NTF  initially  will  be 
capitalized  through  an  expected  contribution  of  about  $13  million  from  the  European 
Commission.  The  Government  then  will  make  increasing  annual  contributions,  intended  to 
eventually  match  sector  maintenance  needs.  The  NTF  also  will  raise  revenue  from  road  user 
charges,  which  are  appropriate  for  transport  infrastructure  preservation.  The  anticipated 
magnitude of the NTF will be sufficient to maintain all rehabilitated roads. 

30. 
It has been proposed that an independent board, comprising a comprehensive range of 
stakeholders  from  the  Government  and  the  private  sector,  should  manage  the  NTF  based  on 
sound  business  principles.  If  the  proposal  is  accepted,  the  board  would  be  required  to  report 
transparently  on  its  current  activities  and  future  plans.  The  operations  of  the  NTF  will  be 
designed  to  ensure  more  needs-related  funding,  as  well  as  a  more  reliable  flow  and  better 
deployment of funding.

31. 
Given its involvement in road maintenance and rehabilitation, the Australian Agency for

maintain the current road network; (iv) ensuring that road design recognizes life cycle costs; (v) 
instituting sustainable arrangements for managing and maintaining roads; (vi) addressing social 
impacts and community involvement; (vii) providing additional resources and skills for MID; and

Contribution of the sector and/or subsector to poverty reduction in Solomon Islands:  

Due  to  several  years  of conflict  (1999–2003),  real  gross domestic  product (GDP)  per capita  declined  by 
35%  to  about  $500.  Since  2003,  GDP  growth  has  averaged  4–5%.  Based  on  projected  economic  and 
population  growth  rates,  the  International  Monetary  Fund  and  the  Central  Bank  of  Solomon  Islands 
estimate  that  the  economy  will  require  another  20  years  to  return  to  the  pre-conflict  level  of  GDP  per 
capita.  The distribution  of national  income  is  highly  uneven between Honiara and  provincial  centers  and 
rural  villages;  between  rich  and  poor;  and  between  women  and  men.  Solomon  Islands,  one  of  the  least 
developed  among  the  Asian  Development  Bank’s  (ADB)  Pacific  developing  member  countries,  ranks 
second  lowest  among  Pacific  island  countries  in  the  United  Nations’  Human  Development  Index.  The 
country is unlikely to meet most of the Millennium Development Goals by 2015.  

The  socioeconomic  situation  is  characterized  by  high  unemployment,  especially  among  the  youth,  and 
rapid  population  growth.  The  annual  population  growth  rate  of  2.9%  is  among  the  highest  in  the  world. 
Combined  with  slow  economic  growth,  this  situation  exacerbates  poverty.  The  economy  is  based  on 
primary commodities from agriculture, forestry, and fishing. Jobs are in short supply everywhere, with little 
formal  employment  outside  the  capital  of  Honiara,  and  scarce  income-generating  opportunities  in  rural 
areas.  Falling  commodity  prices,  deteriorating  rural  infrastructure,  lack  of  rural  services  and  access  to 
markets, and low-productivity traditional cultivation practices hamper rural agricultural development. Poor 
and  expensive  infrastructure  facilities,  lack  of  an  appropriate  legal  and  regulatory  environment,  poor 
business  and  banking  services,  and  a  limited  market  constrain  the  development  of  the  private  sector. 
Solomon Islands has some of the worst education and health statistics in the Pacific, which are a legacy of 
weak public institutions, low public funding, and poor service delivery in these sectors. Poor transportation 
infrastructure, including roads, also hampers access to education and health facilities and services.   

The  Project’s  focus  on  the  rehabilitation  of  provincial  and  secondary  roads  matches  the  Government 
priorities, as set out in the National Economic Reform, Recovery, and Development Plan (NERRDP). The 
entire road network—from feeder roads to national roads—is quickly deteriorating and impassable at many 
points. The network requires urgent improvements to maintain access of the rural population to markets 
and services. Two key objectives are (i) to ensure connections between rural production and markets; and 
(ii) to improve access to health, education, and other services. While contributing to the overarching goal 
of poverty reduction, the rehabilitation of rural roads should be complemented by a long-term strategy to 
ensure  connectivity  between  national,  provincial,  secondary,  and  rural  feeder  roads;  and  cost-effective 
methods to ensure sustainable rehabilitation and maintenance of rural feeder roads.

Land holds tambu (sacred) sites and monuments that represent the history of people’s clans, lineage, and 
society.  Because  of  these  historical  ties,  land  becomes  an  important  link  between  the  living  and  their

The centrality of land to people’s identity implies that the Project needs to work closely and sensitively with

entail gaining access to, and the use of, aggregates on customary land. It also might involve minor road 
realignments, or the reclaiming of the fringes of remnant roads over which de facto property rights have 
developed. Therefore, the Project must establish a credible liaison scheme with communities in the COIs 
for discussing these issues and gaining resource owners’ oral and written consent.

Description of the Environment 

Physical  Resources.  Solomon  Islands  is  an  archipelago  with  a  land  area  of  about 
7. 
28,000 square kilometers in the southwest Pacific. The 992 islands extend 1,667 km southeast. 
Six major island groups make up 80% of the land area in two roughly parallel island chains. The 
northern  group  includes  Choiseul,  Isabel,  and  Malaita,  while  the  southern  group  has  New 
Georgia,  Guadalcanal,  and  Makira.  The  country  is  divided  into  nine  provinces:  Central, 
Choiseul, Guadalcanal, Isabel, Makira, Malaita, Renbel, Temoutu, and Western. 

8. 
Many of the larger islands are rugged, heavily forested, and mountainous, while others 
are  low-lying  coral  atolls.  Topographically,  the  varied  and  rugged  terrain  supports  an 
extraordinary  biodiversity  and  wide  range  of  ecosystems.  Most  of  the  islands  are  of  volcanic 
origin,  surrounded  by  uplifted  coral  terraces  and  fringed  by  coral  reefs.  The  soils  found  in 
Solomon Islands generally are well-drained and deep, though upland soils tend to be clay-rich 
and  poorly  drained.  On  moderate  and  steep  slopes,  the  soils  are  eroded  easily  where 
vegetation has been removed.   

9. 
Solomon  Islands  has  a  tropical  climate  with  a  relatively  high  and  uniform  temperature, 
high humidity, and abundant rainfall. The mean annual rainfall is 3–5 meters, though this varies 
considerably.  Heavy  rains  and  cyclones  generally  occur  in  the  fourth  quarter  of  the  year. 
Extensive  rivers  and  perennial  streams  are  found  on  the  larger  islands  throughout  the 
archipelago. Rural communities obtain water primarily from streams, rivers, and springs, which 
can be vulnerable to contamination. Many communities also harvest rainfall from building roofs 
for drinking water. 

10.  Mitigation  measures  (such  as  terracing,  construction  of  efficient  drains,  and  planting  to 
stabilize  slopes)  will  provide  long-term  beneficial  effects  by  reducing  soil  erosion  and 
sedimentation  of  surface  waters.  Construction  of  well-designed  drainage  systems  capable  of 
handling the high intensity runoff characteristic of the region also will reduce localized flooding. 
Well-engineered  slopes  and  drainage  systems,  combined  with  thorough  planting,  will  reduce 
significantly the likelihood of landslides near the project roads. 

11. 
Ecological  Resources.  Solomon  Islands  has  a  large  number  of  terrestrial  and  marine 
ecosystems, many with exceptionally high biodiversity and endemism. About 80% of the country 
is covered with dense tropical rainforest. The rainforest is an important traditional resource for 
rural communities, providing food, building materials, and medicines. 

12. 
Commercial forestry plays a central role in the economy of Solomon Islands by creating 
jobs and generating revenue. However, when undertaken unsustainably, logging damages the 
environment with long-term irretrievable loss of resources. Soil erosion, contamination of water 
supplies,  loss  of  non-timber  resources,  and  damage  to  coral  reefs  due  to  sedimentation  are 
some  of  the  major  impacts.  The  rate  of  extraction  of  logs  has  risen  sharply  over  the  past  5 
years. At current rates, natural forest resources are projected to be depleted before 2020.  

Fisheries  and  other  marine  resources  are  an  important  component  of  the  natural 
13. 
environment that the rural population heavily depends on. Up to 90% of the country’s population 
relies  on  fish  and  shellfish  as  a  food  source  harvested  largely  from  near-shore  coral  reefs,

lagoons, mangrove swamps, and sea grass beds. The Solomon Islands coral reefs are mainly 
fringing  and  intermittent  around  all  of  the  islands.  The  status  of  coral  reefs  in  the  Solomon 
Islands is relatively unknown, although the large increase in sediment runoff from logged areas 
probably has impacted coral reefs and coastal fisheries severely in many places. 

14.  While  large,  formally  established  protected  areas  are  few,  many  smaller  sites  are 
informally  protected  with  the  assistance  from  nongovernment  organizations,  resource  owners, 
and community groups that that are being successfully managed. These include Kolombangara 
(Western  Province),  the  Bauro  Highlands  (Makira  Province),  and  the  East  Rennell  World 
Heritage site (Renbel Province).  

15. 
Social and Cultural Resources. The vast majority of the population of about 475,000 is 
Melanesian (95%), with the remainder being mostly of Polynesian origin. The population density 
on some 347 islands is about 15 people per km2, one of the lowest in the Pacific. More than half 
of the population is below 15 years old. Malaita and Guadalcanal account for approximately half 
of  the  population.  The  next  largest  populated  area  is  Western  Province  (65,000),  with  roughly 
equal  numbers  of  people  living  in  Choiseul,  Isabel,  Makira,  Central,  and  Temotu  provinces. 
Renbel Province is the most sparsely populated. With an estimated annual growth rate of 2.9% 
over the past 5 years, the population is expected to nearly double by 2050.  

16. 
A prominent feature of the Solomon Islands is the widely dispersed rural population and 
the many small villages, which are home to nearly 75% of the population. The country has an 
estimated 4,200 settlements with an average of 70 people in each and 6 people per household. 
The relatively small population of internally diverse ethnic and linguistic groups dispersed over a 
large,  fragmented  land  area  of  mostly  rugged  terrain  with  a  limited  transportation  and 
communications infrastructure create conditions that hamper the delivery of basic services and 
restrict  economic  growth.  As  a  result,  social  and  health  indicators  are  among  the  worst  in  the 
Pacific. 

17. 
The Solomon Islands has been termed a “dual economy,”  because the rural areas are 
largely  subsistence-based,  while  the  few  main  population  centers  (e.g.,  Honiara)  are  cash-
based. The majority of the country’s population depends almost solely on subsistence activities, 
such  as  vegetable  gardening,  hunting  and/or  gathering,  and  fishing.  Gradually,  subsistence 
groups are becoming more dependent on earning cash—largely from leasing customary lands 
to  logging  companies,  or  exchanging  goods  or  services—which  can  be  used  to  purchase 
manufactured goods and other items not obtainable from the immediate natural environment. 

18. 
An  official  listing  of  sites  of  cultural,  historical,  or  archaeological  importance  is  not 
available.  Within  the  subproject  areas,  the  EARP  will  identify  any  sites  of  clear  cultural 
significance, which will not be disturbed by the road rehabilitation.
